nodes.bodyText: Nit let's line break before .build()
will fix in rev2
Put in visibility order public (none here), package private, private.
Since SDK depends on Guava, I think it's ok for extensions to as well since it's basically free. So can add @VisibleForTesting
will fix in rev2
Can you run ./gradlew googleJavaFormat?

nodes.bodyText:
Can we add tracestate as additional params too? Not sure we'd prefer tracestate= some serialized string or put the KV's directly (probably need to dedupe against our known keys if the latter).
If not now, let's add a TODO to revisit it we shouldn't just drop it if possible.
I'll add a TODO here since we are discussing whether we will put the OT first 8 digit in trace state. I'd do them together.
will fix in rev2

As per 3) should we avoid throwing on null?
https://github.com/open-telemetry/opentelemetry-specification/blob/master/specification/error-handling.md#basic-error-handling-principles
I'm aligning with the default propagator and the official b3/jaeger propagator. How about we keep the same behavior here and create a separate issue to change all propagators?

Think it's better to use .getSpan(context) and check span.getContext().isValid(). From what I can tell, this current method may return an invalid span too, so either we check both null and valid or just valid.
will check valid to align with the default propagator.
Instead of a large catch-all exception, only catch where an exception could happen. Even if we're worried about missing something, this isn't the right layer to have a catch-all.
I'm not sure if internal package is really meant for use from contrib, but similar to above, since this is SDK, we may as well just use Guava and Strings.isNullOrEmpty
Agree we can drop internal package usages. will fix in rev2

We want our instrumentation to have as low an impact on user app's performance as possible so we should take care in optimizing especially parse logic.
This is probably the most optimized version
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-aws/blob/master/brave-propagation-aws/src/main/java/brave/propagation/aws/AWSExtractor.java#L72
Even if that's too complex, we can still get a lot of improvement by avoiding .split in favor of indexOf and substring, I don't think we need to use split at all here (the warning is valid :) )

JDK has a specialized optimization on splitting by single character, which doesn't use regex. See SO post and JDK implementation. Hence I don't think changing to the extractor or substring will make noticeable performance improvement that worths the trade of readability.
It's not about the regex but the allocation of an array is still significant, especially since we don't need it. On the flip side, the change in readability also shouldn't be significant.
Ok that makes sense. Fixing in rev3
When avoiding split we should also inline the key/value parse here to avoid allocating arrays
Same as above
Think we can put them in tracestate, related to above comment. We should do both or neither though not just one.
I'll put a TODO for now
Will fix in rev2. But I want to keep the length check since Sampled=123 is invalid in X-Ray context.
I'd inline the strings, or have constants for the various forms. It's more readable and avoids the issue of now we need a test for this test helper.
Will fix in rev2.

This test doesn't seem to reflect reality and I don't think it actually verifies anything. We've already verified in our other tests that carrier is passed to the setter. So I think we can remove the test.
Will remove in rev2.
Nit I'd put the success cases above the error cases.
Will fix in rev2.
Here especially, don't use a helper method or even a constant, inlining the header will make much more readable what the test is checking.
will fix in rev2
I think these two tests are supposed to use semicolon instead of colon.
The tests are actually invalid. They are copied from B3Propagator tests. I'll remove them.
will fix
will fix
Cool

Recommend instead having inline constants for different types of trace headers, e.g.
TRACE_HEADER_SAMPLED = "Root=11241341413441;Parent=12312134;Sampled=1"
TRACE_HEADER_UNSAMPLED = "Root=11241341413441;Parent=12312134;Sampled=0"
There's some duplication, but since this is testdata, not business logic, doesn't really affect maintenance. But it has a nice benefit that anyone, including people not familiar with X-Ray, can easily see what an X-Ray header is supposed to look like.
ok that's fair. will fix

Couple more test cases

Valid header with keys in different oder
Valid header with additional params. We strip this right now but need to make sure this propagator can read any valid header
Ah can we also add a test where we inject and there's some trace state? Documents that we ignore for now and will give a target to update when actually implementing it.
Sure, will add those tests
Isn't this branch an invalid header?
Oops it should be.
Oops it should be.
I don't think this tests anything different from _Size. But having a test with one character that isn't 0 or 1 seems important
will change to "a"
will fix
If you made the TRACE_ID_VERSION a string, you could avoid the String.valueOf call above, and just use startsWith for this call. Might read a little cleaner in both cases.

I just realized that this means the B3 and Jaeger propagators now depend on guava. I'm concerned that will be surprising, and potentially lead to version conflicts down the road.
Opinions, @carlosalberto and @bogdandrutu ?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -12,6 +12,9 @@ ext.moduleName = "io.opentelemetry.contrib.trace.propagation"
 dependencies {
     api project(':opentelemetry-api')
 
+    implementation libraries.guava,
+            platform(boms.guava)

nodes.bodyText: I'm actually only using the @VisibleForTesting annotation (which I think is valuable for b3 and jaeger propagators as well). The main package has depended on Guava too. IMO thinking long term the contrib will need Guava now or later. It is better to have it before GA
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -12,6 +12,9 @@ ext.moduleName = "io.opentelemetry.contrib.trace.propagation"
 dependencies {
     api project(':opentelemetry-api')
 
+    implementation libraries.guava,
+            platform(boms.guava)

nodes.bodyText: My concern is that you're forcing a guava dependency on the B3 and Jaeger propagators when they don't need it (and likely don't want it). I'd rather just replace the annotation with a comment on those methods, rather than add guava here.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -12,6 +12,9 @@ ext.moduleName = "io.opentelemetry.contrib.trace.propagation"
 dependencies {
     api project(':opentelemetry-api')
 
+    implementation libraries.guava,
+            platform(boms.guava)

nodes.bodyText: We were initially working in the sdk_contrib repo and I think there it makes sense to use Guava where helpful since the sdk depends on it anyways. But agree for the API we don't really need it, at least for now.

 dependencies {
     api project(':opentelemetry-api')
 
+    implementation libraries.guava,
+            platform(boms.guava)

nodes.bodyText: Sounds reasonable. I'll remove the Guava dependencies
